importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The day before the voting in London, President Trump made a public threat on Truth Social to impose sanctions on countries supporting the shipping emissions plan, directly influencing the IMO’s decision to delay the adoption of the Net Zero Framework.
The final vote and announcement of the postponement of the Net Zero Framework occurred on this date, marking a pivotal moment in international climate policy and maritime regulation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Net Zero Framework aims to reduce shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050, making the 2025 postponement a significant setback in global climate action timelines.

keyTakeAways: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed formal approval of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months due to threats from U.S. President Donald Trump.
Trump threatened to impose sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on countries that supported the global carbon tax on shipping, undermining international cooperation.
The Net Zero Framework would have been the first global carbon-pricing system for shipping, charging $380 per metric tonne of excess CO2-equivalent emissions.
Support for the framework was initially strong among 63 IMO members, including China, the EU, Brazil, Britain, and others, but was weakened after Trump’s intervention.
Countries such as Russia and Saudi Arabia opposed the measure, while Argentina and Singapore shifted from support to opposition after the threat.
The decision was criticized by climate advocates, including UN Secretary-General António Guterres and the International Chamber of Shipping, as a missed opportunity for climate action.
The shipping industry faces growing climate-related risks, including more frequent storms and changing ocean currents, making emissions reduction urgent.
Proposed solutions include using cleaner fuels like ammonia and methanol and retrofitting ships with special sails to reduce carbon emissions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) delayed formal approval of its Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened to impose sanctions on countries supporting a global carbon tax on shipping emissions. The NZF, which would have charged ships $380 per metric tonne of excess CO2 emissions and incentivized cleaner fuels, was initially approved in April 2025 by 63 IMO members. However, following Trump’s public criticism and threats of economic penalties on supporting nations, delegates in London voted to postpone adoption, with 57 in favor and 49 opposed. The move has been widely criticized by climate leaders, including UN Secretary-General António Guterres and the International Chamber of Shipping, as a missed opportunity to advance decarbonization in shipping. Countries like China, the EU, and the UK had previously backed the plan, while Russia, Saudi Arabia, Argentina, and Singapore shifted opposition, highlighting the political influence of fossil fuel advocacy and U.S. foreign policy on global climate action.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
